column1: Spokane ( (listen) spoh-KAN) is a city in and the county seat of Spokane County
column2: Washington
column3: United States. It is in eastern Washington along the Spokane River adjacent to the Selkirk Mountains and west of the Rocky Mountain foothills
column4: 92 miles (148 km) south of the Canada–U.S. border
column5: 18 miles (30 km) west of the Washington–Idaho border
column6: and 279 miles (449 km) east of Seattle along Interstate 90.

column1: Spokane is the economic and cultural center of the Spokane metropolitan area
column2: the Spokane–Coeur d'Alene combined statistical area
column3: and the Inland Northwest. It is known as the birthplace of Father's Day
column4: and its official nickname is the "Lilac City". A pink double flower cultivar of the common lilac
column5: known as Syringa vulgaris 'Spokane'
column6: is named for the city. The city and the wider Inland Northwest area are served by Spokane International Airport
column7: 5 miles (8 km) west of downtown Spokane. According to the 2010 Census
column8: Spokane had a population of 208
column10: making it the second-largest city in Washington
column11: and the 100th-largest city in the United States. In 2019
column12: the United States Census Bureau estimated the city's population at 222
column13: 081 and the population of the Spokane Metropolitan Area at 573
column14: 493.The first people to live in the area
column15: the Spokane tribe (their name meaning "children of the sun" in Salishan)
column16: lived off plentiful game. David Thompson explored the area with the westward expansion and establishment of the North West Company's Spokane House in 1810. This trading post was the first long-term European settlement in Washington. Completion of the Northern Pacific Railway in 1881 brought settlers to the Spokane area. The same year it was officially incorporated as a city under the name of Spokane Falls (it was reincorporated under its current name ten years later). In the late 19th century
column17: gold and silver were discovered in the Inland Northwest. The local economy depended on mining
column18: timber
column19: and agriculture until the 1980s. Spokane hosted the first environmentally themed World's Fair at Expo '74.

column1: Many of the downtown area's older Romanesque Revival-style buildings were designed by architect Kirtland Kelsey Cutter after the Great Fire of 1889. The city is also home to the Riverfront and Manito parks
column2: the Smithsonian-affiliated Northwest Museum of Arts and Culture
column3: the Davenport Hotel
column4: and the Fox and Bing Crosby theaters.

column2: and the Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist serves as that of the Episcopal Diocese of Spokane. The Spokane Washington Temple in the east of the county serves The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Gonzaga University was established in 1887 by the Jesuits
column3: and the private Presbyterian Whitworth University  was founded three years later and moved to north Spokane in 1914.In sports

column1: The first humans to live in the Spokane area were hunter-gatherers that lived off plentiful fish and game; early human remains have been dated to 8
column3: 000 years ago. The Spokane tribe
column4: after which the city is named (the name meaning "children of the sun" or "sun people" in Salishan)
column5: [a] are believed to be either their direct descendants
column6: or descendants of people from the Great Plains. When asked by early white explorers
column7: the Spokanes said their ancestors came from "up North." Early in the 19th century
column8: the Northwest Fur Company sent two white fur trappers west of the Rocky Mountains to search for fur. These were the first white men met by the Spokanes
column9: who believed they were sacred
column10: and set the trappers up in the Colville River valley for the winter.

column2: working as head of the North West Company's Columbia Department
column3: became the first European to explore the Inland Empire (now called the Inland Northwest). Crossing what is now the Canada–US border from British Columbia
column4: Thompson wanted to expand the North West Company further south in search of furs. After establishing the Kullyspell House and Saleesh House trading posts in what are now Idaho and Montana
column5: Thompson then attempted to expand further west. He sent out two trappers
column6: Jacques Raphael Finlay and Finan McDonald
column7: to construct a fur trading post on the Spokane River
column8: which flows west from Lake Coeur d'Alene to the Columbia River
column9: and trade with the local Indians. This post was established in 1810
column10: at the confluence of the Little Spokane and Spokane rivers
column11: becoming the first enduring European settlement of significance in what later became Washington state. Known as the Spokane House
column12: or simply "Spokane"
column13: it was in operation from 1810 to 1826. Operations were run by the British North West Company and later the Hudson's Bay Company
column14: and the post was the headquarters of the fur trade between the Rocky and Cascade mountains for 16 years. After the latter business absorbed the North West Company in 1821
column15: the major operations at the Spokane House were eventually shifted north to Fort Colville
column16: reducing the post's significance.In 1836
column17: Reverend Samuel Parker visited the area and reported that around 800 Native Americans were living in Spokane Falls. A medical mission was established by Marcus and Narcissa Whitman to cater for Cayuse Indians and hikers of the Oregon Trail at Walla Walla in the south.

column9: the Coeur d'Alene War of 1858 was brought to a close by the actions of Col. George Wright
column10: who won decisive victories against a confederation of tribes in engagements at the battles of Four Lakes and Spokane Plains. The cessation of hostilities opened the inter-mountain valley of the Pacific Northwest to safe habitation by settlers.

column1: Joint American–British occupation of Oregon Country
column2: in effect since the Treaty of 1818
column3: eventually led to the Oregon Boundary Dispute after a large influx of American settlers along the Oregon Trail. Great Britain ceded its claims to lands in Puget Sound and the central and lower Columbia Basin by the Oregon Treaty of 1846 The Hudson's Bay Company wound up its operations in the area over the next few years.

column1: The first American settlers in what is now Spokane were J.J. Downing and S.R. Scranton
column2: cattle ranchers who squatted and established a claim at Spokane Falls in 1871. Together they built a small sawmill on a claim near the south bank of the falls. James N. Glover and Jasper Matheney
column3: Oregonians passing through the region in 1873
column4: recognized the value of the Spokane River and its falls for the purpose of water power. They realized the investment potential and bought the claims of 160 acres (65 ha) and the sawmill from Downing and Scranton for a total of $4
column5: 000. Glover and Matheney knew that the Northern Pacific Railroad Company had received a government charter to build a main line across this northern route. Amid many delays in construction and uncertainty over the completion of the railroad and its exact course
column6: Matheney sold his interest in the claim to Glover.[b] Glover confidently held on to his claim and became a successful Spokane business owner and the city's second mayor. He later came to be known as the "Father of Spokane".In 1880

column8: at the junction of the Columbia and Spokane Rivers
column9: to protect the construction of the Northern Pacific Railway and secure a place for U.S. settlement. By June 30

column2: silver
column3: and lead in the Coeur d'Alene region of northern Idaho lured prospectors. The Inland Empire erupted with numerous mining rushes from 1883 to 1892. Mining and smelting emerged as a major stimulus to Spokane. At the onset of the initial 1883 gold rush in the nearby Coeur d'Alene mining district
column4: Spokane became popular with prospectors
column5: offering low prices on everything "from a horse to a frying pan". It would keep this status for subsequent rushes in the region due to its trade center status and accessibility to railroad infrastructure.[d]Spokane's growth continued unabated until August 4
column7: when a fire
column8: now known as The Great Fire (not to be confused with the Great Fire of 1910
column9: which happened nearby)
column10: began just after 6:00 p.m.
column11: and destroyed the city's downtown commercial district. Due to technical problems with a pump station
column12: there was no water pressure in the city when the fire started. In a desperate bid to starve the fire
column13: firefighters began razing buildings with dynamite. Eventually the winds and the fire died down; 32 blocks of Spokane's downtown core had been destroyed and one person killed.

column2: and in part because of it
column3: Spokane experienced a building boom.[e] The downtown was rebuilt
column4: and the city was reincorporated under the present name of "Spokane" in 1891. According to historian David H. Stratton
column5: "From the late 1890s to about 1912
column6: a great flurry of construction created a modern urban profile of office buildings
column7: banks
column8: department stores
column9: hotels and other commercial institutions" which stretched from the Spokane River to the site of the Northern Pacific railroad tracks below the South Hill. Yet the rebuilding and development of the city was far from smooth: between 1889 and 1896 alone
column10: all six bridges over the Spokane River were destroyed by floods before their completion. In the 1890s the city was subject to intrastate migration by African-Americans from Roslyn
column11: looking for work after the closure of the area's mines. Two African-American churches
column12: Calvary Baptist and Bethel African Methodist Episcopal
column13: were founded in 1890. Just three years after the fire
column15: James J. Hill's Great Northern Railway arrived in the chosen site for Hill's rail yards
column16: the newly created township of Hillyard (annexed by Spokane in 1924). Spokane became an important rail shipping and transportation hub for the Inland Empire
column17: connecting mines in the Silver Valley with agricultural areas around the Palouse region. The city's population ballooned to 19
column20: 848 in 1900 with the arrival of additional railroads. By 1910 the population had hit 104
column22: and Spokane eclipsed Walla Walla as the commercial center of the Inland Empire. In time the city came to be known as the "capital" of the Inland Empire and the heart of a vast tributary region. After the arrival of the Northern Pacific
column28: Spokane became one of the most important rail centers in the western U.S.

column1: Expansion abruptly stopped in the 1910s and was followed by a period of population decline
column2: due in large part to Spokane's slowing economy. Control of regional mines and resources became increasingly dominated by national corporations rather than local people and organizations
column3: diverting capital outside of Spokane and decreasing growth and investment opportunities in the city. During this time of stagnation
column4: unrest was prevalent among the area's unemployed
column5: who became victimized by "job sharks"
column6: who charged a fee for signing up workers in the logging camps. Job sharks and employment agencies were known to cheat itinerant workers
column7: sometimes paying bribes to periodically fire entire work crews
column8: thus generating repetitive fees for themselves. Crime spiked in the 1890s and 1900s
column9: with eruptions of violent activity involving unions such as the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW)
column10: or "Wobblies" as they were often known
column11: whose free speech fights had begun to garner national attention. Now
column12: with grievances concerning the unethical practices of the employment agencies
column13: they initiated a free speech fight in September 1908 by purposely breaking a city ordinance on soapboxing. With IWW encouragement
column14: union members from many western states came to Spokane to take part in what had become a publicity stunt. Many Wobblies were incarcerated
column15: including feminist labor leader Elizabeth Gurley Flynn
column16: who published her account in the local Industrial Worker.

column1: After mining declined at the turn of the 20th century
column2: agriculture and logging became the primary influences in the Spokane economy. The population explosion and the building of homes
column3: railroads
column4: and mines in northern Idaho and southern British Columbia fueled the logging industry. Although overshadowed in importance by the vast timbered areas on the coastal regions west of the Cascades
column5: and burdened with monopolistic rail freight rates and stiff competition
column6: Spokane became a noted leader in the manufacture of doors
column7: window sashes
column8: blinds
column9: and other planing mill products. Rail freight rates were much higher in Spokane than the rates in coastal seaport cities such as Seattle and Portland
column10: so much so that Minneapolis merchants could ship goods first to Seattle and then back to Spokane for less than shipping directly to Spokane
column11: even though the rail line ran through Spokane on the way to the coast.[f]The Inland Northwest region has also long been associated with farming
column12: especially wheat production. Initially
column13: the Palouse was thought to unsuitable for wheat production due to the hilly terrain
column14: believing wheat could not be cultivated on the tops of the hills
column15: but the region showed great promise for wheat production when it began in the late 1850s in part due to the hilltops. The Palouse was and still is a breadbasket and was able to develop and grow with the completion of several railroad networks as well as a highway system that began to center around the city of Spokane
column16: aiding farmers from around the region in distributing their products to market. Inland Empire farmers exported wheat
column17: livestock and other agricultural products to ports such as New York
column18: Liverpool and Tokyo.Local morale was affected for years by the collapse of the Division Street Bridge early in the morning on December 15
column20: which killed five people and injured over 20
column21: but a new bridge was built (eventually replaced in 1994). The 1920 census showed a net increase of just 35 individuals
column22: which actually indicates that thousands left the city when considering the natural growth rate of a population. Growth in the 1920s and 1930s remained slow but less drastically so
column23: forcing city boosters to market the city as a quiet
column24: comfortable place suitable for raising a family rather than a dynamic community full of opportunity. The Inland Empire was heavily dependent on natural resources and extractive goods produced from mines
column27: which experienced a fall in demand. The situation improved slightly with the start of World War II as aluminum production commenced in Spokane due to the area's cheap electricity (produced from regional dams) and the increased demand for airplanes.

column1: After decades of stagnation and slow growth
column2: Spokane businessmen formed Spokane Unlimited in the early 1960s
column3: an organization that sought to revitalize downtown Spokane. A recreation park showcasing the Spokane Falls was the preferred option
column4: and after successful negotiation to relocate the railroad facilities on Havermale Island
column5: they executed on a proposal to host the first environmentally themed World's Fair in Expo '74 on May 4
column6: becoming the smallest city at the time to host a World's Fair. This event transformed Spokane's downtown
column7: removing a century of railroad infrastructure and re-inventing the urban core. After Expo '74
column8: the fairgrounds became the 100-acre (40 ha) Riverfront Park.The growth witnessed in the late 1970s and early 1980s was interrupted by another U.S. recession in 1981
column9: in which silver
column10: timber
column11: and farm prices dropped. The period of decline for the city lasted into the 1990s and was also marked by a loss of many steady family-wage jobs in the manufacturing sector. At this time
column12: market forces began to impact the local Kaiser Aluminum plant and layoffs
column13: pension cuts
column14: a 1998-1999 labor strike
column15: and eventually bankruptcy in 2002 followed. Although this was a tough period
column16: Spokane's economy had started to benefit from some measure of economic diversification; growing companies such as Key Tronic and other research
column17: marketing
column18: and assembly plants for technology companies helped lessen Spokane's dependence on natural resources.

column2: Spokane is still trying to make the transition to a more service-oriented economy in the face of a less prominent manufacturing sector. Developing the city's strength in the medical and health sciences fields has seen some success
column3: resulting in the expansion of the University District with two medical school branches. The city faces challenges such as a scarcity of high-paying jobs
column4: pockets of poverty
column5: and areas of high crime.The opening of the River Park Square Mall in 1999 served as a catalyst and sparked a downtown rebirth that included the building of the Spokane Arena and expansion of the Spokane Convention Center. Other major projects include the building of the Big Easy concert house (now the Knitting Factory) and renovation of the historic Montvale Hotel
column6: the Kirtland Cutter-designed Davenport Hotel (after being vacant for over 20 years)
column7: the Fox Theater (now home to the Spokane Symphony) as well as the completion of the WSU Pharmaceutical and Biomedical Sciences Building in 2013 and the Davenport Grand Hotel in 2015
column8: Ridpath Hotel in 2018 and the ongoing renovation of Riverfront Park (as of May 2019). The Kendall Yards development on the west side of downtown Spokane is one of the largest construction projects in the city's history. Directly across the Spokane River from downtown
column9: it will blend residential and retail space with plazas and walking trails.

column10: consisting of eastern Washington

column1: Spokane lies in the Northern Rockies ecoregion near the eastern edge of the basaltic Channeled Scablands steppe
column2: a plain that eventually rises sharply to the east towards the rugged
column3: timbered Selkirk Mountains. The foothills of the Rockies—the Coeur d'Alene Mountains—rise about 25 miles (40 km) to the east in north Idaho. The city is in a transition area between the barren landscape of the Columbia Basin and the coniferous forests to the east; to the south are the lush prairies and rolling hills of the Palouse. The highest peak in Spokane County is Mount Spokane
column4: at an elevation of 5
column5: 883 feet (1
column7: on the eastern side of the Selkirk Mountains. The Spokane River is the area's most prominent water feature
column8: a 111-mile (179 km) tributary of the Columbia River
column9: originating from Lake Coeur d'Alene in northern Idaho. The river flows west across the Washington state line through downtown Spokane
column10: meeting Latah Creek
column11: then turns to the northwest
column12: where it is joined by the Little Spokane River on its way to the Columbia River
column13: north of Davenport. The Channeled Scablands and many of the area's numerous large lakes
column14: such as Lake Coeur d'Alene and Lake Pend Oreille
column15: were formed by the Missoula Floods after the ice-dammed Glacial Lake Missoula ruptured at the end of the last ice age. The Turnbull National Wildlife Refuge south of Cheney is the closest natural reserve
column16: the closest National Forest is the Colville National Forest
column17: the closest National Recreation Area is the Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area and the closest national park is Mount Rainier National Park
column18: approximately a four-and-a-half hour drive from Spokane.

column1: Spokane is within the Northern/Canadian Rockies ecoregion
column2: which supports an abundance of wildlife in part because of its varied geology and natural history. The area contains a wide range of vegetation
column3: from densely wooded coniferous forests to rolling grassy hills and meadows. Ponderosa pine and Douglas fir are common in the drier and lower elevation areas throughout the region. The ponderosa pine is the official tree of the City of Spokane
column4: which is where specimens were first collected by botanist David Douglas in 1826.[g]The Canadian Rockies ecoregion supports 70 mammals
column5: 16 reptiles and amphibians
column6: 168 birds
column7: and 41 fish species. There is a high concentration of raptors in the area
column8: bald eagles are a common sight near Lake Coeur d'Alene in December and January when kokanee spawn. The most common fish present in area lakes is the Washington-native rainbow trout
column9: which is the official fish of Washington state. Big game common in eastern Washington include black and grizzly bears
column10: caribou
column11: Rocky Mountain elk
column12: bighorn sheep
column13: and cougar. Whitetail deer
column14: mule deer
column15: and moose are also found in abundance. The gray wolf population has been making a recovery in the Inland Northwest. As of June 2016
column16: there are 16 wolf packs in eastern Washington. In August 2016
column17: photo evidence confirmed a solitary wolf in Mount Spokane State Park.Although the ecoregion remains ecologically intact
column18: it faces conservation challenges that include the negative effects of certain forestry management and logging practices
column19: higher risks of forest fires due to the alteration of the trees that make up the forest composition
column20: and habitat fragmentation as a result of urban sprawl and development
column21: which endangers the long-term survival of vulnerable species such as mountain caribou and the Northern goshawk.

column1: Spokane has a dry summer continental climate (Dsb under the Köppen classification)
column2: a rare climate due to its elevation and significant winter precipitation; Spokane
column3: however
column4: is adjacent to and sometimes even classified as a warm-summer Mediterranean climate (Csb) because the average temperature for the coldest month is just over 26.6 °F (−3 °C).The area typically has a hot
column5: arid climate during the summer months
column6: bracketed by short spring and fall seasons. On average
column7: July and August are equally warm
column8: and the coolest month is December; July averages 69.5 °F (20.8 °C)
column9: while December averages 27.5 °F (−2.5 °C).[h] Daily temperature ranges are large during the summer
column10: often exceeding 30 °F (17 °C)
column11: and small during the winter
column12: with a range just above 10 °F (5.6 °C). The record high and low are 108 °F (42 °C) and −30 °F (−34 °C)
column13: but temperatures of more than 100 °F (38 °C) or less than −10 °F (−23 °C) are rare. Temperatures above 90 °F (32 °C) occur an average of 19 days annually
column14: temperatures above 100 °F (38 °C) occur an average of only 1 day annually
column15: and those below 0 °F (−18 °C) average 3.5 days a year.Spokane's location
column16: between the Cascades Range to the west and the Rocky Mountains to the east and north
column17: protects it from weather patterns experienced in other parts of the Pacific Northwest. The Cascade Mountains form a barrier to the eastward flow of moist and relatively mild air from the Pacific Ocean in winter and cool air in summer. As a result of the rain shadow effect of the Cascades
column18: the Spokane area has 16.5 inches (420 mm) average annual precipitation
column19: less than half of Seattle's 37 inches (940 mm). Most precipitation occurs in December
column20: and summer is the driest time of the year. The Rockies shield Spokane from some of the winter season's coldest air masses traveling southward across Canada.

column1: The City of Spokane operates under a mayor–council form of government
column2: with executive and legislative branches that are elected in non-partisan elections. David Condon was elected mayor in November 2011 and took office on the last business day of the year. The previous mayor was Mary Verner
column3: who succeeded Dennis P. Hession who himself succeeded the recalled James "Jim" West. The city elected James Everett Chase as its first African-American mayor in 1981
column4: and after his retirement
column5: elected the city's first woman mayor
column6: Vicki McNeil. Spokane is the county seat of Spokane County
column7: a position it wrested from Cheney in 1886.Federally
column8: Spokane is within Washington's 5th congressional district
column9: and has been represented in the House of Representatives by Republican Cathy McMorris Rodgers since 2004. Washington State is represented nationally in the Senate by Democrat Patty Murray and Democrat Maria Cantwell. In the 2012 general election
column10: Spokane County favored Mitt Romney for president over Barack Obama by 51.5 to 45.7 percent; on the state ballot
column11: the county supported the legalization of recreational marijuana ballot measure by 52.2 to 47.9 percent and favored the legalization of same-sex marriage by 55.9 to 44.1 percent. Spokane native Tom Foley was a Democratic Speaker of the House and served as a representative of Washington's 5th district for 30 years
column12: enjoying large support from Spokane
column13: until his narrow defeat in the "Republican Revolution" of 1994
column14: the only time U.S. voters have turned out a sitting Speaker of the House since 1860.

The crime woes are possibly due in part to an imbalance that Spokane County prisons receive of pre-release and work-release prisoners; An investigation by the Tacoma News Tribune found that while Spokane County accounts for 6.21 percent of the inmates in state prisons
column12: it receives a disproportionate 16.73 percent of the inmate population to be released into the general population.Spokane and the Spokane Police Department have received national publicity and scrutiny in the 2000s and 2010s due to many officer-involved shootings and allegations of excessive force. The most high-profile of these incidents was the 2006 death of Otto Zehm
column13: a mentally challenged man who was initially suspected of theft at a convenience store. Zehm was later found to have committed no crime

column15: an internal culture audit
column16: and the purchase of body cameras.

column27: the number of people of Russian or Ukrainian ancestry in Spokane County was reported to be 7
column29: 900 residing in the city of Spokane)

column36: after which its population decreased and became integrated and dispersed
column37: losing its Asian character; urban blight and the preparations leading up to Expo '74 led to Chinatown's eventual demolition.

column1: Spokane and its metro area in general
column2: particularly northern Idaho has been stigmatized in the popular consciousness by a number of hate groups that have been set up in and around Coeur d'Alene
column3: Idaho
column4: in the past. Low ethnic diversity made the region a destination for some seeking to escape more cosmopolitan cities for a locale with a relatively homogenous
column5: white population. This trend increased with the arrival of retired engineer Richard Butler from California who traveled to Hayden
column6: Idaho
column7: in 1974 to eventually establish a white supremacist church called the Church of Jesus Christ Christian
column8: better known by its political arm

column10: which led to the eventual bankruptcy and closure of their Hayden compound. Another significant act of hate was the attempted bombing of Spokane's Martin Luther King Day Parade by Kevin Harpham of Addy
column11: Washington in 2011. The Southern Poverty Law Center currently lists three hate groups in the Spokane and Coeur d'Alene metro areas
column12: in the categories of anti-Muslim
column13: Holocaust denial
column14: and general hate.

column1: Spokane's neighborhoods range from the Victorian-style South Hill and Browne's Addition

column1: A National Historic District west of Downtown

column2: created after Expo '74 and occupying the same site

The park also includes the historic hand-carved Riverfront Park Looff carousel created in 1909 by Charles I. D. Looff. Riverfront Park is currently being renovated and modernized (as of October 2016). Manito Park and Botanical Gardens on Spokane's South Hill features the Duncan Gardens

This trail continues on towards Coeur d'Alene for 24 miles (39 km) as the North Idaho Centennial Trail and is often used for alternative transportation and recreational use. In the summer

column1: Spokane became an important rail and shipping center because of its location between mining and farming areas. In the early 1880s
column2: gold and silver were discovered in the Inland Empire; as a regional shipping center
column3: the city furnished supplies to the miners who passed through on their way to the mineral-rich Coeur d'Alene
column4: Colville and Kootenay districts. The mining districts are still considered among the most productive in North America.Natural resources have historically been the foundation of Spokane's economy
column5: with the mining
column6: logging
column7: and agriculture industries providing much of the region's economic activity. After mining declined at the turn of the 20th century
column8: agriculture and logging replaced mining as the primary influences in the economy. Lumberjacks and millmen working in the hundreds of mills along the railroads
column9: rivers
column10: and lakes of northern Washington and Idaho were provisioning themselves in Spokane. Agriculture has always been an important sector in the local economy. The surrounding area
column11: especially to the south is the Palouse
column12: a region that has long been associated with farming
column13: especially wheat production where it is one of the largest wheat producing regions in the United States. As with the mining industry in the late 1880s
column14: Spokane was an important agricultural market and trade center. Inland Empire farmers exported wheat
column15: livestock and other agricultural products to the ports such as New York
column16: Liverpool and Tokyo. Today
column17: a large share of the wheat produced in the region is shipped to Far East markets. The Inland Northwest also supports many vineyards and microbreweries as well. By the early 20th century Spokane was primarily a commercial center rather than an industrial center.

column1: Spokane is known as the birthplace of the national movement started by Sonora Smart Dodd that led to the proposal and eventual establishment of Father's Day as a national holiday in the U.S. The first observation of Father's Day in Spokane was on June 19
column2: 1910. Sonora conceived the idea in Spokane's Central Methodist Episcopal Church
column3: while listening to a Mother's Day sermon.

column2: held in the spring on the first Sunday of May

column6: the "Lilac City"

column13: held every February

column16: held every November

column18: independent films of interest to the GLBT community.Other notable events in the Spokane region include the Spokane County Interstate Fair

column22: demonstrating the many commonalities shared between the two cities. Students from the Spokane campus of Mukogawa Fort Wright Institute

column1: Serving the general educational needs of the local population are two public library districts

column3: the Spokane Public Library system comprises a downtown library overlooking the Spokane Falls and five branch libraries. Special collections focus on Inland Pacific Northwest history and include reference books
column4: periodicals
column5: maps
column6: photographs
column7: and other archival materials and government documents.Spokane Public Schools (District 81) was organized in 1889
column8: and is the largest public school system in Spokane
column9: and the second-largest in the state
column10: as of 2014
column11: serving roughly 30
column12: 000 students in six high schools
column13: six middle schools
column14: and thirty-four elementary schools. Other public school districts in the Spokane area include the Mead School District in north Spokane County
column15: outside city limits. A variety of state-approved
column16: independent charter schools and private and parochial elementary and secondary schools augment the public school system. The Roman Catholic Diocese of Spokane manages ten such schools in & around the area.Spokane is home to many higher education institutions. They include the private universities Gonzaga and Whitworth
column17: and the public Community Colleges of Spokane system (Spokane Community College and Spokane Falls Community College) as well as a variety of technical institutes. Gonzaga University and Law School were founded by the Italian-born priest Joseph Cataldo and the Jesuits in 1887. Whitworth was founded in Tacoma
column18: Washington in 1890 and moved to its present location in 1914. It is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church and had 2
column19: 500 students studying in 53 different undergraduate and degree programs as of 2011. While Spokane is one of the larger cities in the U.S. to lack a main campus of a state-supported university within its city limits
column20: Eastern Washington University (EWU) and Washington State University (WSU) have operations at the Riverpoint Campus in the University District
column21: just adjacent to downtown and across the Spokane River from the Gonzaga campus. Washington State University Spokane is WSU's health sciences campus and houses the school's College of Nursing
column23: and Elson S. Floyd College of Medicine. The main EWU campus is located 15 miles (24 km) southwest of Spokane in nearby Cheney
column24: and WSU is located 65 miles (105 km) to the south in Pullman. In addition to WSU's health science presence in Spokane
column25: there is also a four-year medical school branch affiliated with the University of Washington's WWAMI program. An international branch campus of the Mukogawa Women's University

column1: Spokane is close to dozens of lakes and rivers for outdoor sports and recreation. People use these for swimming
column2: boating
column3: kayaking
column4: rafting
column5: and fishing. Nearby mountains provide for skiing

column3: and Spokane Chiefs in junior ice hockey. Collegiate sports in Spokane focus on the local teams such as the Gonzaga Bulldogs who compete in the NCAA's Division I West Coast Conference and the Whitworth Pirates playing in the Division III Northwest Conference and local media covers other regional teams
column4: including the Eastern Washington Eagles
column5: Washington State Cougars
column6: and the Idaho Vandals.The Spokane Indians located in the suburb Spokane Valley

column8: 803-seat Avista Stadium and have won seven NWL titles since their Short-Season-A debut in 1982. Prior to 1982
column9: the Indians played at the Triple-A level. The team achieved considerable success in the early 1970s
column10: winning the Pacific Coast League championship in 1970
column11: and having a 94–52 record. In the 1920s and 1930s the Spokane City League
column12: a semiprofessional baseball league of teams of the Inland Empire
column13: reached its peak.The Spokane Chiefs are a junior ice hockey team that play in the Canadian Hockey League's Western Hockey League. They play their home games in the Spokane Arena and have a regional rivalry with the Tri-City Americans. They have won the CHL's top prize
column14: the Memorial Cup
column15: two times in club history
column16: first in 1991 and again in 2008.The Spokane Veterans Memorial Arena is the city's premier sports venue. In the years since the Spokane Arena opened
column17: it has played host to several major sporting events. The first major event was the 1998 Memorial Cup
column18: the championship game of the Canadian Hockey League. Four years later in 2002
column19: the city hosted the 2002 Skate America figure skating competition and then the 2007 U.S. Figure Skating Championships in the Spokane Arena. The latter event set an attendance record
column21: 000 tickets. Spokane later hosted the 2010 U.S. Figure Skating Championships – ending eighteen days before the start of the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver
column22: British Columbia and then the 2016 Team Challenge Cup.

column1: Spokane's streets use a grid plan that is oriented to the four cardinal directions; generally
column2: the east–west roads are designated as avenues
column3: and the north–south roads are referred to as streets. Major east–west thoroughfares in the city include Francis
column4: Wellesley
column5: Mission
column6: Sprague
column7: and 29th Avenues. Major north–south thoroughfares include Maple–Ash
column8: Monroe
column9: Division
column10: Hamilton
column11: Greene–Market (north of I-90)
column12: and Ray–Freya (south of I-90) Streets. Division Street divides the city into East and West
column13: while Sprague Avenue splits the city into North and South. Division Street is Spokane's major retail corridor; Sprague Avenue serves the same purpose in Spokane Valley. With over 40
column14: 000 vehicles per day in average daily traffic from Interstate 90 north to the US 2–US 395 junction
column15: North Division is Spokane's busiest corridor.Spokane's extensive skywalk system covers thirteen blocks in the downtown area and is among the largest in the United States; it is used for pedestrian travel in cold and inclement weather and retail space as well. Despite this
column16: the city has an average Walk Score of 49 as of 2020
column17: indicating that most errands require a car. Its average Bike Score is 52.

column2: Spokane's electric streetcar and interurban lines played a dominant role in moving people and goods around Spokane. Streetcars were installed as early as 1888
column3: when they were pulled by horses. Many older side streets in Spokane still have visible streetcar rails embedded in them. Streetcar service was reduced due to declining ridership beginning in 1922
column4: and by August 1936
column5: all lines had been abandoned or converted to motor buses. Mass transportation throughout the Spokane area is provided by the Spokane Transit Authority (STA)
column6: which operates a fleet of 156 buses. Its service area covers roughly 248 square miles (640 km2) and reaches 85 percent of the county's population. A large percentage of STA bus routes originate from the central hub
column7: the STA Plaza in downtown Spokane. Spokane has a Transit Score of 35.4 on Walk Score. Spokane has rail and bus service provided by Amtrak and Greyhound via the Spokane Intermodal Center. The city is a stop for Amtrak's Empire Builder on its way to and from Chicago's Union Station en route to Seattle and Portland. Amtrak's through service to Seattle and Portland is a legacy of BNSF Railway's old Spokane
column8: Portland and Seattle Railway trackage. Spokane is a major railway junction for the BNSF Railway and the Union Pacific Railroad and is the western terminus for the Montana Rail Link.

column12: and Sandpoint. US 195
column13: also known as the Inland Empire Highway
column14: connects to Interstate 90 west of Spokane near Latah Creek and travels south through the Palouse.The Washington State Department of Transportation (WSDOT) is tasked with improving local highways to keep up with the region's growth and to try to prevent congestion problems that plague many larger cities. The WSDOT is constructing the North Spokane Corridor. When completed
column15: the corridor will be a 10.5-mile-long (16.9 km) limited-access highway that will run from I-90
column16: in the vicinity of the Thor/Freya interchange
column17: northward through Spokane
column18: meeting the existing US 395 just south of the Wandermere Golf Course.

column2: ICAO: KGEG) serves as the primary commercial airport for Spokane
column3: Eastern Washington
column4: and Northern Idaho. It is the second-largest airport in the state of Washington
column5: and is recognized by the Federal Aviation Administration as a small hub
column6: with service from six airlines and two air cargo carriers. The 4
column7: 800-acre (19.42 km2) airport is located 5 miles (8.0 km) west of downtown Spokane and is approximately a 10-minute drive away. The international airport's three-letter designation is "GEG"
column8: a result and legacy of the Geiger Field days prior to 1960
column9: when the airport was named after Army aviator Major Harold Geiger in 1941.Felts Field is a general aviation airport serving the Spokane area and is located in east Spokane along the south bank of the Spokane River. Aviation at Felts Field dates back to 1913 and the strip served as Spokane's primary airport until commercial air traffic was redirected to Geiger Field after World War II. In 1927
column10: the strip was one of the first in the western U.S. to receive official recognition as an airport by the U.S. Department of Commerce and is now named in honor of James Buell Felts
column11: a Washington Air National Guard pilot.

column1: The Spokane area has six major hospitals
column2: four of which are full-service facilities. The health-care industry is a large and increasingly important industry in Spokane; the city provides specialized care to many patients from the surrounding Inland Northwest and as far north as the Canada–US border. The city's health-care needs are served primarily by non-profit Seattle-based Providence Health & Services and non-profit Tacoma-based Multicare Health System
column3: which run the two biggest hospitals
column4: Sacred Heart Medical Center
column5: and Deaconess Hospital
column6: respectively. These two hospitals
column7: the St. Luke's Rehabilitation Institute
column8: and most of Spokane's major health-care facilities
column9: are located on Spokane's Lower-South Hill
column10: just south of downtown
column11: in what is known as the "Medical District" of Spokane. Sacred Heart Hospital opened originally with just 31 beds on Spokane Falls Boulevard on January 27
column13: but later moved to its present location at 101 West Eighth Avenue. As of 2014 it had 642 beds
column14: with 28
column15: 319 admissions
column17: 543 emergency room visits
column18: and 2
column20: and a full-time staff of 29 doctors and dentists and 583 registered nurses. Deaconess Medical Center
column21: the smaller of the two main hospitals
column22: had 388 beds as of 2014. Other hospitals in the area include the Spokane Veterans Affairs Medical Center in the northwest part of town
column23: Holy Family Hospital on the north side
column24: and Valley Hospital and Medical Center in the Spokane Valley. One of 20 specialty orthopedic Shriners Hospitals in the U.S. is also located in Spokane. One of Washington's two state psychiatric hospitals
column26: is located 15 miles (24 km) away in Medical Lake.

column1: The City of Spokane provides municipal water
column2: wastewater management
column3: and solid waste management. Spokane operates Washington's only waste-to-energy plant as well as two solid waste transfer stations as part of the Spokane Regional Solid Waste System
column4: a collaboration between the City of Spokane and Spokane County. Electricity generated by the waste-to-energy plant is used to operate the facility
column5: with excess energy being sold to Puget Sound Energy. Spokane draws its water from the Spokane Valley–Rathdrum Prairie Aquifer; this 370-square-mile (958 km2) "sole source aquifer" is the only water supply for Spokane County in Washington
column6: and for Kootenai and Bonner counties in Idaho. Serving over 500
column7: 000 people
column8: the aquifer is distinguished in being one of the largest aquifers in the country at 10 trillion gallons
column9: as well as having one of the fastest flow rates in the country at 60 feet (18 m) per day
column10: and for its purity.[i]Natural gas and electricity are provided by the local utility
column11: Avista Utilities
column12: while CenturyLink and Comcast provide television
column13: internet
column14: and telephone service. Spokane hosts three hydroelectric generation facilities on the Spokane River: the Upriver Dam
column15: the Upper Falls Dam
column16: and the Monroe Street Dam. The Upriver Dam is owned and operated by the City of Spokane
column17: and generates the electricity needed to operate the municipal water supply's pressure pumps. The power generated in excess of that is sold to Avista Utilities. The Upper Falls and Monroe Street dams are owned and operated by Avista Utilities
column18: and have respective generation capacities of 10 and 15 MW.

column1: Newspaper service in Spokane is provided by its only major daily newspaper
column2: The Spokesman-Review
column3: which has a daily circulation of 76
column4: 291 and Sunday circulation of 95
column5: 939. The Spokesman-Review was formed from the merger of the Spokane Falls Review (1883–1894) and the Spokesman (1890–1893) in 1893 and was first published under the present name on June 29
column6: 1894. It later absorbed the competing afternoon paper The Spokane Daily Chronicle
column7: a significant newspaper that existed from 1881 until 1982.[j] More specialized publications include the weekly alternative newspaper The Pacific Northwest Inlander
column8: the bi-weekly Spokane Journal of Business
column9: and the student-run Gonzaga Bulletin. Monthly publications include The Black Lens
column10: an African American community newspaper
column11: a newspaper for parents
column12: Kids Newspaper
column13: and a home and lifestyle magazine
column14: Spokane Coeur d'Alene Living.According to Arbitron
column15: Spokane is the 94th-largest radio market in the U.S.
column16: with 532
column17: 100 listeners aged 12 and over. There are 28 AM and FM radio stations broadcast in the city. The five most listened-to stations are KKZX-FM (classic rock)
column18: KQNT-AM (news/talk)
column21: and KZZU-FM (Hot AC). Spokane's primary sources of non-commercial and community radio include Spokane's NPR-affiliate station KPBX-FM and KYRS
column22: a full-power community radio station.Spokane is the 73rd-largest television market in the U.S.
column23: accounting for 0.366% of the total TV households in the U.S. The city has six television stations
column24: representing the major commercial networks and public television. Spokane is the television broadcast center for much of eastern Washington (except the Yakima and Tri-Cities area)
column28: and parts of southern Canada (by cable television). Spokane receives broadcasts in the Pacific Time Zone
column29: with weekday prime time beginning at 8 pm. Montana and Alberta
column30: Canada are in the Mountain Time Zone and receive Spokane broadcasts one hour later by their local time. The major network television affiliates include KREM (TV) 2 (CBS)
column38: and KCDT-TV 26 (PBS; operating out of Coeur d'Alene
